data.title: Javascript Parameters with properties and Intellisense
data.body:
Currently intellisense does not detect parameter properties see [http://usejsdoc.org/tags-param.html](url) for details.

![not-working](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5748243/13590266/014821a2-e4a4-11e5-9d75-d75d00b6b639.PNG)

Is this something that support will be added for?

data.title: editor.formatOnType breaks indentation
data.body:
This is for version 0.10.10, when writing JavaScript.

It appears that setting "editor.formatOnType" to true breaks indentation when you add a newline. What I mean by this is that if you are at the end of a line, and hit "enter", the keyboard cursor will briefly appear at the right indentation level on the new line, but snap back to the line start after about 100 milliseconds.

Setting formatOnType to false fixes this behavior; but, of course, VS Code will no longer format on type. Perhaps whatever code formatter is being used is configured to remove all indentation for empty lines.

The only other custom setting that I have is setting "insertSpaces" to false.

data.title: JavaScript code formatting not working properly after v0.10.10
data.body:
We are extensively using javascript auto format code feature in vs code to reduce js lint errors.
Ex: spaces after function and function name etc ...

after updating to v0.10.10 above formatting is not working any more and it reset all the formatted functions without spaces.

Can someone help or give information how to override this rule ?

var test = function() { }; //this is what new version format js code to.

but we are expecting and previously worked before like below.
var test = function () { };

data.title: Make Intellisense font and image size adjustable

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
I was playing around with the `editor.fontSize` setting in VSCode because I am a little nearsighted.
Is there a way to also have the font either inherit the size from the `editor.fontSize` setting or create a new one for it?
 Keep in mind when you scale the font, the images to the left need to be scaled as well.

data.title: Variables starting with "let" or "var" break highlight.
Packaging  the Mac App
data.body: Hey There,  Loving VS Code, it's awesome so far. I pulled down and built from source today and was wondering what you use to generate the Mac app. I saw the resources for generating the .deb .rpm, but I didn't quite see a place where a could build the app and have the final result be an OSX app. Is there a specific tool or command you are using?

data.title: [webkit-debug-adapter] Path must be a string. Received undefined
JavaScript Intellisense not working for commonJS after upgrading to 0.10.10
data.body:
I updated to 0.10.10 today, hoping to try out the new JavaScript support with Salsa. Unfortunately, my Intellisense has stopped working. I am using type definition files from definitely typed (e.g. the express.d.ts).

For example, using 0.10.8:

var exp = require("express");
exp.Router

I will see the content assist for the "Router" function and I can visit the definition file by right clicking on "Router" > Go to Definition

Now when I do the same thing in 0.10.10, I don't see "Router" in the Intellisense list. In addition, the list seems to have variables I had defined earlier in my code (which doesn't apply to express at all).

data.title: New `code` shell command fails if `python` points to Python 3
data.body:
Just installed 0.10.10 and installed the `code` shell command:

```
$ code --help
  File "<string>", line 1
    import os,sys; print os.path.realpath(sys.argv[1])
                          ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax
/usr/local/bin/code: line 10: ./MacOS/Electron: No such file or directory
```

VS Code itself works fine if I launch it via Spotlight.

I believe the problem is that I had a Python virtual environment active, and `python` points to Python 3. If I try `code` outside of that virtualenv, where `python` means Python 2, everything works fine.

I guess the options are:
1. Make the launch script Python 2/3 compatible. (Step one would probably be to add `from __future__ import print_function` and update the `print` statements accordingly.)
2. Do some extra work to guarantee that you launch the system Python and not the user's configured Python, though this is probably not a viable long-term approach since distributions like Fedora now [default to Python 3](https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Changes/Python_3_as_Default) and don't even install Python 2 by default.

data.title: Pass debug configuration name to vscode.startDebug
data.body:
It'd be nice to be able to start a debugging session from command line. eg:
code my_workspace --debug name_of_my_configuration_in_launchjson

Other features we could use to simulate this would be the ability for extensions to read the currently selected debug configuration, and a way to set it, or the ability to pass it as a parameter to workbench.action.debug.start.

data.title: Allow bracket matching style customization
data.body:
From doc feedback verbatim:
"I'm trying to find out how to change the highlight style of the bracket matching from its current near invisibility regardless of theme to something usable. One shouldn't have to create a whole theme to accomplish this commonly requested customization in all editors/IDEs--just have editor prefs for bracket matching style:[underline|box] and weight:[light|medium|heavy] and color:[#xxxxxx]"

data.title: Autocomplete accessibility glitch

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
There's something odd going on when typing actual code into Vs Code. To reproduce:
1. Create a file called index.html.
2. Type <html> .
3. Press enter.
Expected behavior:
The cursor goes to the next line.
Perceived behavior:
Nothing actually happens. You have to press Enter again to go to the next line.

Expected cause: I think an autocomplete list pops up that the accessibility stack isn't aware of. Pressing the first enter likely selects the first option in this list.
Problem with this hypothesis: Arrowing up and down should make different things happen if my theory is correct, however it doesn't seem to do that. Therefore I am not a 100% sure I am correct, someone comment on it to check please.
I think fixing this so the prsumed opup is correctly handled should be the next step for accessibility of this product.

data.title: poor syntax highlighting for javascript/react files
data.body:
Code looks like a plain text file, until it parses the `<>` jsx tags. Atom has way more visual information about the syntax. Is there anything missing? Is this a bug?

data.title: Javascript keywords broken
data.body: "function" and "var" don't seem to be keywords in javascript now after the update. (0.10.10 FEB 2016)

data.title: Key binding Ctrl+Alt+L and AltGr+L are euqal but shouldn't
data.body:
I installed the extension https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=alefragnani.Bookmarks

I belive the extension is working correctly, however I see a problem with key binding.

In the "Default Keyboard Shortcuts" is like that:

``` JSON
{ "key": "ctrl+alt+l",            "command": "bookmarks.jumpToNext",
                                     "when": "editorTextFocus" },
```

According to extension docs `Ctrl+Alt+L` shuld be "jump to next" - this combination of keys is working as described.

However on my system (Windows10) the key combination: `AltGr+L` (right Alt + L and no Ctrl key) is also working for this task, and this is a problem.

`AltGr+L` on my keyboard reserved for a letter `ł`, I can rebind the key combination used by extension but this indicate that in general there should be a difference between `CTRL+Alt` and `AltGr`.

data.title: VSCode should flag errors on tsconfig.json

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
VS Code does not report errors in `tsconfig.json`, and then silently drops the ball without telling the user. This is particularly annoying since some things might continue working, while others mysteriously stop.

Errors in `tsconfig.json` come in two flavours – actual syntactical errors, but also unrecognized new properties. In particular the latter is annoying, for example when TypeScript adds new features such as `--allowUnreachableCode` (see #3428).

My suggestion would be to at least visibly and loudly report this, but preferably be more lenient about what's accepted (e.g. unrecognized properties).

data.title: Test Tour: React Starter Kit
data.body:
There is some overlap with other test tour, but this starter kit deserves to be hit hard. It is very popular.

data.body:
1. Clone [php slim starter](https://github.com/xsanisty/SlimStarter)
2. Install popular [PHP extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=felixfbecker.php-debug).
3. Run sample app and confirm it works as expected.

data.title: Test Tour: Python
data.body:
1. Clone the [Python Django sample app](https://github.com/kirpit/django-sample-app). 
2. Install [popular Python extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=donjayamanne.python)
3. Run the app and confirm that there are no errors. 
4. Tryout python debugging

data.title: Call out code blocks more prominently
data.body:
Currently this is how we show code blocks. 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/13575871/e01a7598-e43f-11e5-978f-cc7c447b02cb.png)

One thing I really miss from Sublime is the Bracket Highlighter package. 

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2449568/13576040/89cb07f6-e440-11e5-810d-19afc587f7b3.png)

It would be great to have some sort of option here. I don't believe there is a way to do this with the current extension api. My feature request is to expose something in the extension api or to make it a product feature.

data.title: Ignore / suppress errors / warnings
data.body: Occasionally I have an error or a warning I don't want to see anymore. I can't figure out a way to ignore the error.

data.title: Unity - TBD
Missing keyboard shortcut features from Sublime Text
data.body:
I created an [extension](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=ms-vscode.sublime-keybindings) to port Sublime keybindings to VS Code keybindings. I made a list of all the key bindings that were missing analogous commands in VS Code. 

Here is the list roughly ordered by importance. Please let me know about more I missed in the comments. If an extension exists with the functionality I added it in the far right column. 

| Windows / Linux | Mac | Description | Issue | Extension |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+left mouse click | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+left mouse click | Add multi cursors | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/3130 | None | 
| <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>;</kbd> | None | Go to Word | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14028 | None |
| <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>+</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>+</kbd> and <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>=</kbd> | Increase Font Size | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14031 | [FontSize Shortcuts](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=peterjuras.fontsize-shortcuts) |
| <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>-</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>-</kbd> | Decrease Font Size | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14031 | [FontSize Shortcuts](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=peterjuras.fontsize-shortcuts) |
| <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>m</kbd> | <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>m</kbd> | Expand selection to brackets | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14089 | [Bracket Selection](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=guosong.bracketselection) |
| <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>j</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>j</kbd> | Expand selection to indent level | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14090 | None |
| <kbd>alt</kbd>+<kbd>q</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>alt</kbd>+<kbd>q</kbd> | Break / Wrap line | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14093 | None |
| <kbd>alt</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>1</kbd> | <kbd>alt</kbd>+<kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>1</kbd> | Switch to single column view | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14094 | None |
| <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>y</kbd> | <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>y</kbd> | Repeat | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14097 | None |
| <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>a</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>a</kbd> | Expand selection to tag | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14098 | [expand-region](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=letrieu.expand-region) |
| <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>space</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>space</kbd> | Expand selection to scope | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14099 | [expand-region](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=letrieu.expand-region) |
| <kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>f11</kbd> | <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>f</kbd> | Enter distraction free mode | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/12940 | None |
| <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>space</kbd> | <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>space</kbd> | Select next auto complete suggestion | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14101 | None |
| <kbd>alt</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>w</kbd> | <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>w</kbd> | Wrap HTML tag | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14103 | None |
| <kbd>alt</kbd>+<kbd>.</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>alt</kbd>+<kbd>.</kbd> | Close HTML tag | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14104 | [Close HTML/XML tag](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=Compulim.compulim-vscode-closetag) |
| <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>k</kbd> <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>6</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>k</kbd> <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>6</kbd> | Fold level 6 | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14106 | None |
| <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>k</kbd> <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>7</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>k</kbd> <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>7</kbd> | Fold level 7 | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14106 | None |
| <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>k</kbd> <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>8</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>k</kbd> <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>8</kbd> | Fold level 8 | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14106 | None |
| <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>k</kbd> <kbd>ctrl</kbd>+<kbd>9</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>k</kbd> <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>9</kbd> | Fold level 9 | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14106 | None |
| <kbd>alt</kbd>+<kbd>0</kbd> | <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>0</kbd> | Select open tab index 9 | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/14095 | None |


Additionally, here are other actions that are not bound to a keyboard shortcut:

| Action | Issue | Extension |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Drag and drop selected text | https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/1046 | None |

* Customize keybinding support in menus (see this comment https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/3776#issuecomment-260324787)
* Customize keybinding support in viewlets (see this https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/4557)

data.title: Test Tour: Unity - TBD
Cannot use a local gulp path that works on all platforms
data.body:
In my task.json I would like to use the "gulp" installed in the project's node_modules instead of a globally installed gulp. On OS X and Linux I was able to use:

``` json
"command": "node_modules/.bin/gulp",
```

But this does not work on Windows because there I have to use backslashes.

``` json
"command": "node_modules\\.bin\\gulp",
```

It would be great if this limitation could be lifted.

data.title: Extension for Logstash configuration syntax highlighting/completion

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: This would be a great extension to have in VSCode.  I'm sure there are many other people that would appreciate it.

data.title: Support projects with multiple tsconfig.json
data.body:
We have a project that consists of multiple typescript projects, as it's conceptually the same project for us we does not want to open only subsets of it. Atom supports this case, but it would be great if VS Code supported it too.

An example of the folder structure is:

```
client/
  lib/
    app.ts
  tsconfig.json
server/
  some-service
    lib/
      service.ts
    tsconfig.json
```

data.title: Markdown: Support to follow local links

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
It is possible to follow local links for the markdown?

For example, I have two splits for a markdown file: one for editing, and the other one for previewing. If I have a local link `[Installation](installation.md)`. When clicking this link in the preview split, is it possible for both the two splits automatically switch to installation.md?

Further, is it possible to sync two scroll bars for the preview split and the edit split?

data.title: Hiding the menu bar does not indicate how to bring it back
Focus with keyboard to message bar Hard to see
data.body: At least, I can't find a way to set focus there so that I can navigate to the various options and choose one.
